bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Jorge LeRoy y Cassa, August 27, 1927

div1.p: Kean expresses his disappointment in the competition between Cuba and America regarding the credit for the yellow fever work. According to Kean, it was Reed who demonstrated Finlay's theory and Gorgas who applied it.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Jorge LeRoy y Cassa, August 27, 1927

COPY
Reed and Finlay
25 August, 1927.
Dr. Jorge Le-Roy y Cassa,
Jefe de Demografia Sanitaria Nacional,
c/o Secretaria de Sanidad y Beneficencia,
Habana, Cuba.
FROM GEN. J. R. KEAN
My dear Dr. Le-Roy:
div1.p:
I have been much pleased to receive the Boletin Oficial, Nos.
1, 2 and 3 bound together, containing the interesting and eloquent addresses
of Dr. Lopez del Vallo, Dr. Lebredo and Dr. Duque with reference to the fine
achievements of our departed friends, Dr. Finlay, Dr. Guiteras and Dr. Diego
Tamayo. I have also read with great interest your article Revindicacion
de la Gloria de Finlay, and it is with reference to this that I wish to say
a few words.

The conquest of yellow fever is a glorious episode in which Dr.
Finlay, Major Reed and his coadjutors, Lazear, Agramonte, Carroll, General
Gorgas and Dr. Guiteras all bore important and distinguished parts, as well
as a number of other loyal and capable workers. Of these, I think we can
agree, three names stand out more prominently - Finlay who originated the
theory of the transmission of yellow fever by the mosquito; Reed who was
the directing mind in the wonderful scientific demonstration in 1900-1901
which caused its acceptance by the civilized world, and Gorgas who on a
great scale successfully applied the theory enunciated by Finlay and demon-
strated by Reed so as to make a conquest of this great plague. I loved and
admired both Dr. Finlay and Dr. Reed and it is distressing to me to see a
spirit of rivalry grow up between Cuba and the United States as to the
division of the glory between them. I entirely agree with you that the
word “discovery” is not the proper word to apply to Reed's work. I am
accustomed to use the word “demonstrated” or “proved”. The line of this
division was long ago pointed out by our good friend Guiteras, and when
I mention the circumstances you will doubtless recall them. I recently
read in my diary, written at the time, a brief account of the dinner gotten
up by Dr. Guiteras and some other physicians of Havana (on Dec. 22nd 1900)
to celebrate the demonstration by the Reed Commission of the truth of the
theory of Finlay. This demonstration had been recently accepted by the
Yellow Fever Board of Havana of which both Drs. Finlay and Guiteras were mem-
bers. At that dinner, sitting between Dr. Finlay and Dr. Reed, Dr. Guiteras
spoke, with the eloquence and precision which was his gift, of the glory of
these two men. He compared the discovery of the method of transmission of
yellow fever to that which had been accomplished a year or two before with
regard to malaria and said that the part of Finlay corresponded to that of
Patrick Manson who clearly enunciated the theory, while the work of Reed
corresponded to that of Ronald Rose who gave to this theory the scientific
FROM GEN. J. R. KEAN
2.
demonstration which was necessary in order that the scientific world
should accept it. This division of the glory seemed to all of us at the
time to be appropriate and just and I can not see why there should ever
be an departure from it. The theory was and is the theory of Finlay.
The demonstration of it so as to cause its acceptance by the medical
profession of the world belongs to Reed and his assistants. The epi-
demiological arguments which Dr. Finlay brought forward to support his
theory were very strong but his experiments all failed because of two
factors which were necessary to the successful transmission of disease
experimentally. These were, of course, first the twelve day period of
incubation in the mosquito, and, second the fact that the yellow fever
patient ceases to be infective for the mosquito after the third day.
I discussed this failure with Dr. Finlay and went over his experiments
with him. His notes were so full and clear that it could be demonstrated
that each one of his experiments failed to fulfill either one condition
or the other. Therefore, it could only be claimed that he had produced
a case of yellow fever by allowing a very long period of incubation in
one or two patients who, by the way, were not protected from infection by
other mosquitoes.

Therefore, Dr. Finlay failed in twenty years to make a single
prominent convert among the leaders of the medical profession, so far as
I know, either in Cuba or abroad. It is my recollection that neither
Dr. Guiteras or the other members of the Yellow Fever Board of Havana
believed in the mosquito transmission of yellow fever until the experi-
ments of Reed made it impossible of doubt. One of the last members of that
board to be convinced was Gorgas. In the words of Goldberger “Reed con-
verted a discredited theory into an established doctrine.” There are many
other examples in medicine of such a division of credit between the orig-
inal proponent of a theory and the man whose scientific demonstration,
usually in a laboratory, causes the world to accept the theory. Dr. Oliver
Wendell Holmes who besides being a poet and essayist was a professor of
medicine at Harvard declared the infectious character of puerpual fever
and its transmission to women by the hands of their attendants. This
theory was, however, not accepted until some years afterwards the Austrian
Sommelweiss demonstrated the truth of the theory so that it was generally
accepted. In the same way Dr. A. F. A. King of Washington in 1882 read
a paper before the Philosophical Society of Washington which he afterwards
published in the Popular Science Monthly for September, 1883 in which he
boldly and clearly announced the transmission of malaria by mosquitoes and
gave many epidemiological arguments in support of this theory. In this
paper, by the way, he refers to Dr. Finlay's work in Havana. His theory
remained, however, barren of practical results until the demonstration
by Ross and the Italian group converted it into an established doctrine.
Since these facts are so, it appears to me as unjust and unscientific for
Cubans to claim all the credit for Finlay as for Americans to fail to give
Finlay his due share of the glory. To invoke the Seventh Commandment
seems to me to be rather harsh language on either side; rather should be
invoked that spirit of justice which should be an attribute of the scien-
tific mind.

It gives me great pleasure to read the Boletin Oficial de
la Secretaria de Sanidad y Beneficencia, and I often hope that I may
some day have the pleasure of another visit to Cuba to see again my
good friends there of whom I shall always count you as one.
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, J. R. KEAN
Colonel, U. S. Army, Retired
Editor.
The Military Surgeon JRK/W
Note May 14 1946- Several years ago Dr. Francisco Dominguez
a distinguished doctor of Havana (now dead) sent me his
book written in French written in the centennial year of Dr. Finlay,
birth in which he claims that Finlays inoculation experiments
with yellow fever were successful. He gives a very interesting
account of the dinner to Doctor Finlay on Dec. 22 1900 by
the doctors of Havana. He says that he got up the dinner
at General Woods request and he presided and made the
principal address which I have ascribed to Dr. Juan Guiteras.
How the accounts of two reputable persons as to the same
dinner can differ so widely I cannot imagine. My knowledge
of Spanish was imperfect but my conversation with Dr. Finlay
was in English and I knew the chief speaker Dr Guiteras
very well.
Dr. Dominguez & Carlos E. Finlay & others now
claim for Dr. F several successful cases.
The case of Rev. Padre Uma looks like one.
